Ordered Indices

  • Ordered index(ìˆœì„œ ì¸ë±ìŠ¤): index entriesê°€ search key ê°’ì— ë”°ë¼ ì •ë ¬ë˜ì–´ ì €ì¥

Multilevel Index

B +^++ -Tree(and B-Tree) Index Files

B +^++ -Tree Index Files

  • Index-sequential file organizationì˜ Disadvantage(ë‹¨ì )
    • íŒŒì¼ì´ ì»¤ì§ì— ë”°ë¼ overflow blocksì´ ë§ì´ ìƒì„±ë˜ì–´ ì„±ëŠ¥ ì €í•˜(ì¸ë±ìŠ¤ ì¡°íšŒ ë° ìˆœì°¨ ìŠ¤ìº” ëª¨ë‘)
    • ë¹„ìš©ì´ ë§ì´ ë“¤ê³  ì£¼ê¸°ì ì¸ ì „ì²´ íŒŒì¼ reorganization(ì¬êµ¬ì„±)ì´ í•„ìš”
  • B +^++ -tree index structureì˜ Advantage(ì¥ì )
    • Insertion(ì‚½ì…) ë° deletion(ì‚­ì œ) ì‹œ small, local changes(ì‘ê³  êµ­ì†Œì ì¸ ë³€ê²½)ë¡œ ìë™ìœ¼ë¡œ self-reorganizes(ìì²´ ì¬êµ¬ì„±)
    • ì„±ëŠ¥ ìœ ì§€ë¥¼ ìœ„í•´ ì „ì²´ íŒŒì¼ì˜ reorganizationì´ í•„ìš”í•˜ì§€ ì•ŠìŒ
  • B +^++ -treesì˜(Minor) disadvantage((ì‚¬ì†Œí•œ) ë‹¨ì )
    • Extra insertion and deletion overhead, space overhead(ì¶”ê°€ì ì¸ ì‚½ì… ë° ì‚­ì œ ì˜¤ë²„í—¤ë“œ, ê³µê°„ ì˜¤ë²„í—¤ë“œ)
  • B +^++ -treesì˜ ì¥ì ì´ ë‹¨ì ë³´ë‹¤ í¬ê¸° ë•Œë¬¸ì— extensively(ê´‘ë²”ìœ„í•˜ê²Œ) ì‚¬ìš©ë¨
  • B +^++ -treeëŠ” ë‹¤ìŒ ì†ì„±ì„ ë§Œì¡±í•˜ëŠ” rooted tree(ë£¨íŠ¸ê°€ ìˆëŠ” íŠ¸ë¦¬)
    • Rootì—ì„œ leaf(ë¦¬í”„)ê¹Œì§€ì˜ ëª¨ë“  ê²½ë¡œëŠ” ê¸¸ì´ê°€ ê°™ìŒ: Balanced tree(ê· í˜• íŠ¸ë¦¬)
    • Rootë‚˜ leafê°€ ì•„ë‹Œ ê° node(i.e., internal node(ë‚´ë¶€ ë…¸ë“œ))ëŠ” âŒˆn/2âŒ‰\lceil n/2 \rceilâŒˆn/2âŒ‰ì™€ nnn ì‚¬ì´ì˜ children(ìì‹)ì„ ê°€ì§(nnnì€ íŠ¹ì • íŠ¸ë¦¬ì— ëŒ€í•´ ê³ ì •)
      • At least âŒˆn/2âŒ‰\lceil n/2 \rceilâŒˆn/2âŒ‰ and at most nnn children(pointers)
    • Leaf nodeëŠ” âŒˆ(nâˆ’1)/2âŒ‰\lceil(n-1)/2 \rceilâŒˆ(nâˆ’1)/2âŒ‰ì™€ nâˆ’1n-1nâˆ’1 ì‚¬ì´ì˜ values(ê°’)ì„ ê°€ì§
      • At least âŒˆ(nâˆ’1)/2âŒ‰\lceil(n-1)/2 \rceilâŒˆ(nâˆ’1)/2âŒ‰ and at most nâˆ’1n-1nâˆ’1 values(not pointers)
    • Special cases(íŠ¹ìˆ˜ ê²½ìš°)
      • Rootê°€ leafê°€ ì•„ë‹Œ ê²½ìš°, at least 2 childrenì„ ê°€ì§
      • Rootê°€ leafì¸ ê²½ìš°(ì¦‰, íŠ¸ë¦¬ì— ë‹¤ë¥¸ ë…¸ë“œê°€ ì—†ëŠ” ê²½ìš°), 0ê³¼ nâˆ’1n-1nâˆ’1 ì‚¬ì´ì˜ valuesë¥¼ ê°€ì§ˆ ìˆ˜ ìˆìŒ
  • B +^++ -treeëŠ” multilevel index(ë‹¤ë‹¨ê³„ ì¸ë±ìŠ¤)ì´ì§€ë§Œ, multilevel index-sequential fileê³¼ëŠ” ë‹¤ë¥¸ êµ¬ì¡°ë¥¼ ê°€ì§

B +^++ -Tree Node Structure

  • Typical node(ì¼ë°˜ì ì¸ ë…¸ë“œ)
    P1P_1P1â€‹K1K_1K1â€‹P2P_2P2â€‹...Pn+1P_{n+1}Pn+1â€‹Kn+1K_{n + 1}Kn+1â€‹PnP_nPnâ€‹
    • KiK_iKiâ€‹ëŠ” search-key values
    • PiP_iPiâ€‹ëŠ” children(non-leaf nodesì˜ ê²½ìš°) ë˜ëŠ” records/buckets of records(leaf nodesì˜ ê²½ìš°)ì— ëŒ€í•œ pointers
    • Note: ìµœëŒ€ nnnê°œì˜ pointersì™€ nâˆ’1n-1nâˆ’1ê°œì˜ key valuesê°€ ìˆì„ ìˆ˜ ìˆìŒ
    • ë…¸ë“œ ë‚´ì˜ search-keysëŠ” ordered(ìˆœì„œê°€ ì§€ì •ë¨): K1<K2<K3<â‹¯<Knâˆ’1K_1 < K_2 < K_3 < \dots < K_{n-1}K1â€‹<K2â€‹<K3â€‹<â‹¯<Knâˆ’1â€‹ (ì´ˆê¸°ì—ëŠ” ì¤‘ë³µ í‚¤ê°€ ì—†ë‹¤ê³  ê°€ì •)

Leaf Nodes in B +^++ -Trees

  • Leaf nodeì˜ Properties(ì†ì„±)
    • i=Â 1,2,â€¦,nâˆ’1i =~1, 2, \dots, n-1i=Â 1,2,â€¦,nâˆ’1ì— ëŒ€í•´, pointer PiP_iPiâ€‹ëŠ” search-key value KiK_iKiâ€‹ë¥¼ ê°€ì§„ file recordë¥¼ ê°€ë¦¬í‚´

    • PnP_nPnâ€‹ì€ search-key orderë¡œ next leaf node(ë‹¤ìŒ leaf node)ë¥¼ ê°€ë¦¬í‚´

Observations about B +^++ -trees

  • Inter-node connections(ë…¸ë“œ ê°„ ì—°ê²°)ì´ pointersë¡œ ì´ë£¨ì–´ì§€ê¸° ë•Œë¬¸ì—, "logically(ë…¼ë¦¬ì ìœ¼ë¡œ)" ê°€ê¹Œìš´ blocksì´ "physically(ë¬¼ë¦¬ì ìœ¼ë¡œ)" ê°€ê¹Œìš¸ í•„ìš”ëŠ” ì—†ìŒ

Queries on B +^++ -Trees: Point Query

function find(v)
1. Set C = root node
2. while(C is not a leaf node) begin
   Let i = smallest number s.t. v â‰¤ C.Ki
   if there is no such number i then
      /* v is larger than every key in C */
      Set C = the node pointed by the last non-null pointer in C
   else if(v = C.Ki ) Set C = C.Pi +1
   else set C = C.Pi /* v < C.Ki */
   end
   /* Now, C is a leaf node */
3. if for some i, Ki = v then return C.Pi
4. else return null /* no record with search-key value v exists */

  • function findRange(lb, ub)ëŠ” lbâ‰¤Vâ‰¤ub\text{lb} \le V \le \text{ub}lbâ‰¤Vâ‰¤ubì¸ search key value VVVë¥¼ ê°€ì§„ ëª¨ë“  ë ˆì½”ë“œ ì§‘í•©ì„ ë°˜í™˜ -~1. CCC=$ \text{lb} $ê°€ ë‚˜íƒ€ë‚  leaf nodeë¥¼ ì°¾ìŒ( find(v)ì—ì„œ CCCë¥¼ ì°¾ëŠ” ê²ƒê³¼ ë™ì¼)
      1. iÂ =Â Ci~=~CiÂ =Â C ì—ì„œ Kiâ‰¥lbK_i \ge \text{lb}Kiâ€‹â‰¥lbì¸ smallest value(ê°€ì¥ ì‘ì€ ê°’)
      1. while(Kiâ‰¤ubK_i \le \text{ub}Kiâ€‹â‰¤ub)
      • C.PiC.P_iC.Piâ€‹ë¥¼ resultsì— Add
      • iÂ =Â iÂ +Â 1i~=~i~+~1iÂ =Â iÂ +Â 1 (if more records inCCC) or move to the next leaf node setting i=Â 1i =~1i=Â 1
  • Real implementations(ì‹¤ì œ êµ¬í˜„)ì€ ì¼ë°˜ì ìœ¼ë¡œ next() í•¨ìˆ˜ë¥¼ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ì—¬ ì¼ì¹˜í•˜ëŠ” ë ˆì½”ë“œë¥¼ one at a time(í•œ ë²ˆì— í•˜ë‚˜ì”©) ê°€ì ¸ì˜¤ëŠ” iterator interface(ë°˜ë³µì ì¸í„°í˜ì´ìŠ¤)ë¥¼ ì œê³µ

Queries on B +^++ -Trees: Cost Analysis

  • íŒŒì¼ì— KKKê°œì˜ search-key valuesê°€ ìˆëŠ” ê²½ìš°, íŠ¸ë¦¬ì˜ heightëŠ” âŒˆlogâ¡âŒˆn/2âŒ‰(K)âŒ‰\lceil \log_{\lceil n/2 \rceil}(K) \rceilâŒˆlogâŒˆn/2âŒ‰â€‹(K)âŒ‰ë¥¼ ì´ˆê³¼í•˜ì§€ ì•ŠìŒ
  • NodeëŠ” ì¼ë°˜ì ìœ¼ë¡œ disk block(ë””ìŠ¤í¬ ë¸”ë¡)ê³¼ ê°™ì€ í¬ê¸°, ì¼ë°˜ì ìœ¼ë¡œ 4KB

    • Rootì—ì„œ leafê¹Œì§€ì˜ index lookup(ì¸ë±ìŠ¤ ì¡°íšŒ)ì— ëŒ€í•´ At most âŒˆlogâ¡50(1,000,000)âŒ‰=4\lceil \log_{50}(1,000,000) \rceil = 4âŒˆlog50â€‹(1,000,000)âŒ‰=4 nodes accessed(ì ‘ê·¼) -~1 million search key valuesë¥¼ ê°€ì§„ balanced binary tree(ê· í˜• ì´ì§„ íŠ¸ë¦¬)ì™€ ë¹„êµ: ì¡°íšŒ ì‹œ ì•½ 20 nodes accessed
    • ëª¨ë“  node accessëŠ” disk I/Oë¥¼ í•„ìš”ë¡œ í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆìœ¼ë©°, ì•½ 20 millisecondsì˜ ë¹„ìš©ì´ ë“¤ê¸° ë•Œë¬¸ì— ìœ„ì˜ ì°¨ì´ëŠ” significant(ì¤‘ìš”)
  • Indexë¥¼ traverse(ìˆœíšŒ)í•œ í›„, ì¼ì¹˜í•˜ëŠ” ë ˆì½”ë“œë¥¼ fetch(ê°€ì ¸ì˜¤ê¸°) ìœ„í•´ one more(random) I/Oê°€ í•„ìš”

Updates on B +^++ -Trees: Deletion

    • Nodeì™€ sibling ì‚¬ì´ì— pointersë¥¼ redistributeí•˜ì—¬ ë‘˜ ë‹¤ minimum number of entries(â‰¥âŒˆ(nâˆ’1)/2âŒ‰\ge \lceil(n-1)/2 \rceilâ‰¥âŒˆ(nâˆ’1)/2âŒ‰)ë³´ë‹¤ more(ë” ë§ì´) ê°€ì§€ë„ë¡ í•¨
    • Nodeì˜ parentì—ì„œ corresponding search-key value(í•´ë‹¹ search-key ê°’)ë¥¼ Update
  • Node deletionsëŠ” ì‚­ì œ í›„ âŒˆn/2âŒ‰\lceil n/2 \rceilâŒˆn/2âŒ‰ê°œ ì´ìƒì˜ pointersë¥¼ ê°€ì§„ nodeë¥¼ ì°¾ì„ ë•Œê¹Œì§€ cascade upwards(ìœ„ë¡œ ì „íŒŒ)ë  ìˆ˜ ìˆìŒ(Note: internal nodeëŠ” at least âŒˆn/2âŒ‰\lceil n/2 \rceilâŒˆn/2âŒ‰ pointersë¥¼ ê°€ì ¸ì•¼ í•¨)

Complexity of B +^++ -Tree Updates

  • Insertion ë° deletion of a single entryì˜ Cost(I/O ì‘ì—… ìˆ˜ ì¸¡ë©´ì—ì„œ)ëŠ” íŠ¸ë¦¬ì˜ heightì— proportional(ë¹„ë¡€)
  • KKKê°œì˜ entriesì™€ ìµœëŒ€ fanout(ë¶„ê¸°ìˆ˜) nnnì´ ìˆëŠ” ê²½ìš°, entryì˜ insert/deleteì˜ worst-case complexityëŠ” O(logâ¡âŒˆn/2âŒ‰(K))O(\log_{\lceil n/2 \rceil}(K))O(logâŒˆn/2âŒ‰â€‹(K))
  • In practice(ì‹¤ì œë¡œëŠ”), I/O ì‘ì—… ìˆ˜ëŠ” less(ë” ì ìŒ)
    • Internal nodesëŠ” buffer(ë²„í¼)ì— ìˆëŠ” ê²½í–¥ì´ ìˆìŒ
    • Splits/mergesëŠ” rare(ë“œë¬¼ê³ ), ëŒ€ë¶€ë¶„ì˜ insert/delete ì‘ì—…ì€ only affect a leaf node(leaf nodeë§Œ ì˜í–¥)
  • Average node occupancy(í‰ê·  ë…¸ë“œ ì ìœ ìœ¨)ëŠ” insertion orderì— depends on(ë‹¬ë ¤ ìˆìŒ)
    • Random insertion(ë¬´ì‘ìœ„ ì‚½ì…) ì‹œ â‰¥2/3\ge 2/3â‰¥2/3
    • Sorted order(ì •ë ¬ëœ ìˆœì„œ)ë¡œ ì‚½ì… ì‹œ 1/21/21/2

B +^++ -Tree File Organization

  • B +^++ -Tree 'File' Organization
    • B +^++ -tree file organizationì˜ Leaf nodesëŠ” pointers ëŒ€ì‹  records(ë ˆì½”ë“œ)ë¥¼ ì €ì¥
    • Insertion/deletion/updatesê°€ ìˆì„ ë•Œë„ data recordsë¥¼ clustered(í´ëŸ¬ìŠ¤í„°ë§)ëœ ìƒíƒœë¡œ ìœ ì§€í•˜ëŠ” ë° ë„ì›€ â†’\toâ†’ data file degradation problem(overflow blocks) í•´ê²°
    • Leaf nodesëŠ” ì—¬ì „íˆ half full(ì ˆë°˜) ìƒíƒœê°€ ìš”êµ¬ë¨
    • Recordsê°€ pointersë³´ë‹¤ í¬ê¸° ë•Œë¬¸ì—, leaf nodeì— ì €ì¥í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆëŠ” recordsì˜ maximum numberëŠ” non-leaf nodeì˜ pointers ìˆ˜ë³´ë‹¤ less(ì ìŒ)
    • Good space utilization(ì¢‹ì€ ê³µê°„ í™œìš©)ì´ ì¤‘ìš”
      • Splits ë° merges ë™ì•ˆ redistribution(ì¬ë¶„ë°°)ì— more sibling nodes(ë” ë§ì€ í˜•ì œ ë…¸ë“œ)ë¥¼ í¬í•¨ì‹œí‚´
      • Redistributionì— 2 siblingsë¥¼ í¬í•¨ì‹œí‚¤ë©´(split/mergeë¥¼ í”¼í•˜ê¸° ìœ„í•´), ê° nodeëŠ” at least âŒŠ3n/4âŒ‹\lfloor 3n/4 \rfloorâŒŠ3n/4âŒ‹ entriesë¥¼ ê°€ì§€ê²Œ ë¨
    • Insertion ë° deletionì€ B +^++ -tree indexì—ì„œ entriesì˜ insertion ë° deletionê³¼ ë™ì¼í•œ ë°©ì‹ìœ¼ë¡œ ì²˜ë¦¬

B-Tree Index Files

  • B +^++ -treeì™€ ìœ ì‚¬í•˜ì§€ë§Œ, B-treeëŠ” search-key valuesê°€ only once(í•œ ë²ˆë§Œ) ë‚˜íƒ€ë‚˜ë„ë¡ í—ˆìš©. Redundant storage of search keys(search keyì˜ ì¤‘ë³µ ì €ì¥)ë¥¼ ì œê±°

  • Non-leaf nodesì˜ search keysëŠ” B-treeì˜ ì–´ë””ì—ë„ ë‚˜íƒ€ë‚˜ì§€ ì•ŠìŒ. Non-leaf nodeì˜ ê° search keyì— ëŒ€í•´ additional pointer field(ì¶”ê°€ í¬ì¸í„° í•„ë“œ)ê°€ í¬í•¨ë˜ì–´ì•¼ í•¨

  • Generalized B-tree leaf node

  • Non-leaf node: pointers BiB_iBiâ€‹ëŠ” bucket ë˜ëŠ” file record pointers

  • Advantages of B-Tree indices

    • Corresponding B +^++ -Treeë³´ë‹¤ May use less tree nodes(ë” ì ì€ ìˆ˜ì˜ íŠ¸ë¦¬ ë…¸ë“œë¥¼ ì‚¬ìš©í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆìŒ)
    • ë•Œë•Œë¡œ leaf nodeì— ë„ë‹¬í•˜ê¸° ì „ì— search-key valueë¥¼ find(ì°¾ëŠ” ê²ƒì´ ê°€ëŠ¥)

  • Disadvantages of B-Tree indices

    • Only small fraction(ì‘ì€ ë¶€ë¶„)ì˜ search-key valuesë§Œ ì¼ì° ë°œê²¬ë¨
    • Non-leaf nodesëŠ” larger(ë” í¬ë¯€ë¡œ), fan-outì´ reduced(ê°ì†Œ) â†’\toâ†’ B-TreesëŠ” ì¼ë°˜ì ìœ¼ë¡œ corresponding B +^++ -Treeë³´ë‹¤ greater depth(ë” í° ê¹Šì´)ë¥¼ ê°€ì§
    • Insertion ë° deletionì´ B +^++ -Treesë³´ë‹¤ more complicated(ë” ë³µì¡)

    • Typically, B-Treesì˜ ì¥ì ì€ ë‹¨ì ë³´ë‹¤ out weigh(í¬ì§€ ì•ŠìŒ)

Other Issues in Indexing

  • Record relocation(ë ˆì½”ë“œ ì¬ë°°ì¹˜) and secondary indices

      • Recordë¥¼ ì°¾ê¸° ìœ„í•´ file organizationì˜ Extra traversal(ì¶”ê°€ ìˆœíšŒ)

  • Indexing strings(ë¬¸ìì—´ ì¸ë±ì‹±)

  • Efficient alternative~1(íš¨ìœ¨ì ì¸ ëŒ€ì•ˆ~1)

    • Much improved IO performance(í›¨ì”¬ í–¥ìƒëœ IO ì„±ëŠ¥), but most leaf nodes half full

Hash Indices

  • Bucket: â‰¥Â 1\ge~1â‰¥Â 1 index entriesë¥¼ í¬í•¨í•˜ëŠ” storage unit(ì €ì¥ ë‹¨ìœ„)(ì¼ë°˜ì ìœ¼ë¡œ disk block)

  • Hash functionì€ access, insertion, deletionì„ ìœ„í•œ entriesë¥¼ locate(ì°¾ëŠ” ë°) ì‚¬ìš©

Static Hashing

  • In a hash index(í•´ì‹œ ì¸ë±ìŠ¤), bucketsì€ recordsì— ëŒ€í•œ pointersë¥¼ ê°€ì§„ entriesë¥¼ ì €ì¥(i.e., buckets store index entries)

    • Insufficient buckets(ë¶ˆì¶©ë¶„í•œ ë²„í‚·)

Hash Functions

  • Hash functionsì€ uniform(ê· ì¼) and random(ë¬´ì‘ìœ„)ì´ ìš”êµ¬ë¨
  • Uniform: ê° bucketì— all theoretically possible values(ëª¨ë“  ì´ë¡ ì ìœ¼ë¡œ ê°€ëŠ¥í•œ ê°’) ì§‘í•©ì—ì„œ same numberì˜ search-key valuesê°€ í• ë‹¹ë¨
  • Random: ê° bucketì€ íŒŒì¼ ë‚´ search-key valuesì˜ actual distribution(ì‹¤ì œ ë¶„í¬)ì— irrespective(ê´€ê³„ì—†ì´), same numberì˜ entriesê°€ í• ë‹¹ë¨
  • Typical hash functions(ì¼ë°˜ì ì¸ í•´ì‹œ í•¨ìˆ˜)ëŠ” search-keyì˜ internal binary representation(ë‚´ë¶€ ì´ì§„ í‘œí˜„)ì— ëŒ€í•œ computation(ê³„ì‚°)ì„ ìˆ˜í–‰
    • E.g., string search-keyì˜ ê²½ìš°, stringì˜ ëª¨ë“  characters(ë¬¸ì)ì˜ binary representationsë¥¼ addedí•˜ê³ , sum modulo the number of buckets(í•©ê³„ë¥¼ ë²„í‚· ìˆ˜ë¡œ ë‚˜ëˆˆ ë‚˜ë¨¸ì§€)ë¥¼ returned(ë°˜í™˜)

Handling of Bucket Overflows

  • Overflow chainingì„ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ëŠ” Hash indexing: closed addressing(íì‡„ ì£¼ì†Œ ì§€ì •)(or closed hashing(íì‡„ í•´ì‹±))

Deficiencies of Static Hashing

  • Static hashingì—ì„œ, í•¨ìˆ˜ hhhëŠ” search-key valuesë¥¼ fixed set(BBB)ì˜ bucket addressesë¡œ ë§¤í•‘. DatabasesëŠ” ì‹œê°„ì´ ì§€ë‚¨ì— ë”°ë¼ grow or shrink(ì»¤ì§€ê±°ë‚˜ ì¤„ì–´ë“¦)
    • Initial number of bucketsê°€ too smallì´ê³ , íŒŒì¼ì´ grows(ì»¤ì§€ë©´), too much overflows(ë„ˆë¬´ ë§ì€ ì˜¤ë²„í”Œë¡œ)ë¡œ ì¸í•´ ì„±ëŠ¥ì´ degrade(ì €í•˜)ë¨
    • Anticipated growth(ì˜ˆìƒë˜ëŠ” ì„±ì¥)ì„ ìœ„í•´ spaceê°€ í• ë‹¹ë˜ë©´, initially(ì´ˆê¸°ì—) ìƒë‹¹í•œ ì–‘ì˜ spaceê°€ wasted(ë‚­ë¹„)ë¨(and buckets will be underfull(ëœ ì±„ì›Œì§))
    • Databaseê°€ shrinks(ì¤„ì–´ë“¤ë©´), again spaceê°€ wastedë¨
  • One solution(í•˜ë‚˜ì˜ í•´ê²°ì±…)
    • New hash functionìœ¼ë¡œ íŒŒì¼ì˜ Periodic re-organization(ì£¼ê¸°ì ì¸ ì¬êµ¬ì„±)
    • Expensive(ë¹„ìš©ì´ ë§ì´ ë“¤ê³ ), disrupts normal operations(ì •ìƒì ì¸ ì‘ì—…ì„ ë°©í•´)
  • Better solution(ë” ë‚˜ì€ í•´ê²°ì±…): Dynamic Hashing(ë™ì  í•´ì‹±)

    • Sizeê°€ grows and shrinksí•˜ëŠ” databaseì— Good

    • Extendable hashing(í™•ì¥ ê°€ëŠ¥ í•´ì‹±): ë™ì  í•´ì‹±ì˜ í•œ í˜•íƒœ(êµì¬ Section 24.5.2 ì°¸ì¡°)

Comparison of Ordered Indexing and Hashing

  • Periodic re-organizationì˜ Cost
  • Insertions and deletionsì˜ Relative frequency(ìƒëŒ€ ë¹ˆë„)
  • Is it desirable to optimize average access time at the expense of worst-case access time?(ìµœì•…ì˜ ê²½ìš° ì ‘ê·¼ ì‹œê°„ì„ í¬ìƒí•˜ì—¬ í‰ê·  ì ‘ê·¼ ì‹œê°„ì„ ìµœì í™”í•˜ëŠ” ê²ƒì´ ë°”ëŒì§í•œê°€?)
  • Expected type of queries(ì˜ˆìƒë˜ëŠ” ì¿¼ë¦¬ ìœ í˜•)
    • Hashingì€ ì¼ë°˜ì ìœ¼ë¡œ keyì˜ specified valueë¥¼ ê°€ì§„ recordsë¥¼ retrieving(ê²€ìƒ‰)í•˜ëŠ” ë° better(ë” ì¢‹ìŒ)
    • Range queriesê°€ common(í”í•œ ê²½ìš°), ordered indicesê°€ preferred(ì„ í˜¸ë¨)
  • In practice(ì‹¤ì œë¡œëŠ”)
    • PostgreSQLì€ hash indicesë¥¼ ì§€ì›í•˜ì§€ë§Œ, poor performance(ì €ì¡°í•œ ì„±ëŠ¥)ë¡œ ì¸í•´ discourages use(ì‚¬ìš©ì„ ê¶Œì¥í•˜ì§€ ì•ŠìŒ)
    • Oracleì€ static hash organizationì„ ì§€ì›í•˜ì§€ë§Œ, not hash indices(í•´ì‹œ ì¸ë±ìŠ¤ëŠ” ì•„ë‹˜)
    • SQLServerëŠ” only B +^++ -treesë¥¼ ì§€ì›
